message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the tear suggests an anal fissure, which occurs in the posterior midline of the anal canal, distal to the pectinate line. Option A is the correct answer. Options B and C are incorrect because they are not in the posterior midline, and option D is incorrect because it is not in the midline.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The longitudinal tear and bright red bleeding are consistent with an anal fissure. Anal fissures are typically located in the posterior midline of the anal canal, distal to the pectinate line. Option A is the correct answer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest that the patient has an anal fissure, which is a tear in the lining of the anal canal. Anal fissures most commonly occur in the posterior midline of the anal canal, which is distal to the pectinate line. Therefore, the correct answer is (A).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The longitudinal perianal tear suggests the patient has an anal fissure. Among the options, only option A correctly describes the location of where an anal fissure occurs, which is posterior midline of the anal canal, distal to the pectinate line.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of bright red blood on toilet paper after wiping indicates a tear in the anal canal, also known as an anal fissure. The location of the tear is most commonly in the posterior midline of the anal canal, distal to the pectinate line. This location is associated with increased risk of injury due to the presence of less elastic tissue and increased pressure during defecation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The longitudinal tear and bright red blood on toilet paper suggest anal fissure, which is usually located in the posterior midline of the anal canal distal to the pectinate line. The other options are incorrect as they either involve the anterior midline, proximal to the pectinate line, or the lateral aspect of the anal canal.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest anal fissure, which is a tear in the lining of the anal canal. The tear usually occurs in the posterior midline of the anal canal, distal to the pectinate line, which is the boundary between the upper two-thirds and lower one-third of the anal canal. This area is supplied by somatic fibers from the inferior rectal branch of the pudendal nerve, which is responsible for the anal pain during defecation. The other options refer to locations that are less likely to cause the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of anal pain and bright red blood on toilet paper suggest an anal fissure. The location of the tear on the posterior midline of the anal canal, distal to the pectinate line, corresponds to the most common location of anal fissures. This is due to the fact that the blood supply to this area is poor, leading to ischemic injury and tear formation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The longitudinal tear and bright red blood suggest an anal fissure. Anal fissures usually occur in the posterior midline of the anal canal, distal to the pectinate line, which is the area supplied by somatic innervation and is more prone to injury. Option A is the only one that matches this description.

Anal fissures usually occur in the posterior midline of the anal canal, distal to the pectinate line. Therefore, the correct answer is (A).
